awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Reconstructing Late Holocene Ecosystem and Climate Shifts from Peat Records in the Western Antarctic Peninsula
awd_abstract_narration:
Warming on the western Antarctic Peninsula in the later 20th century has caused widespread changes in the cryosphere (ice and snow) and terrestrial ecosystems. These recent changes along with longer-term climate and ecosystem histories will be deciphered using peat deposits. Peat accumulation can be used to assess the rate of glacial retreat and provide insight into ecological processes on newly deglaciated landscapes in the Antarctic Peninsula. This project builds on data suggesting recent ecosystem transformations that are linked to past climate of the western Antarctic Peninsula and provide a timeline to assess the extent and rate of recent glacial change. The study will produce a climate record for the coastal low-elevation terrestrial region, which will refine the major climate shifts of up to 6 degrees C in the recent past (last 12,000 years). A novel terrestrial record of the recent glacial history will provide insight into observed changes in climate and sea-ice dynamics in the western Antarctic Peninsula and allow for comparison with off-shore climate records captured in sediments. Observations and discoveries from this project will be disseminated to local schools and science centers. The project provides training and career development for a postdoctoral scientist as well as graduate and undergraduate students.

The research presents a new systematic survey to reconstruct ecosystem and climate change for the coastal low-elevation areas on the western Antarctic Peninsula (AP) using proxy records preserved in late Holocene peat deposits. Moss and peat samples will be collected and analyzed to generate a comprehensive data set of late-Holocene climate change and ecosystem dynamics. The goal is to document and understand the transformations of landscape and terrestrial ecosystems on the western AP during the late Holocene. The testable hypothesis is that coastal regions have experienced greater climate variability than evidenced in ice-core records and that past warmth has facilitated dramatic ecosystem and cryosphere response. A primary product of the project is a robust reconstruction of late Holocene climate changes for coastal low-elevation terrestrial areas using multiple lines of evidence from peat-based biological and geochemical proxies, which will be used to compare with climate records derived from marine sediments and ice cores from the AP region. These data will be used to test several ideas related to novel peat-forming ecosystems (such as Antarctic hairgrass bogs) in past warmer climates and climate controls over ecosystem establishment and migration to help assess the nature of the Little Ice Age cooling and cryosphere response. The chronology of peat cores will be established by radiocarbon dating of macrofossils and Bayesian modeling. The high-resolution time series of ecosystem and climate changes will help put the observed recent changes into a long-term context to bridge climate dynamics over different time scales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As ice-free terrain expands and glaciers recede in response to climate changes, terrestrial ecosystems of the Antarctic Peninsula are changing and will likely continue to undergo transformation in the coming decades. To put these recent and ongoing changes into context, and to better understand the long-term climate and ecological dynamics of the region, we developed paleoenvironmental reconstructions of Holocene climate and ecological changes from the western Antarctic Peninsula. Records of terrestrial paleoclimate, like those obtained from peat and lake sediment cores, are scarce and sporadically distributed on the Antarctic Peninsula, but these sources of information can provide paleoclimate evidence complimentary to ice-core and marine-sediment records. Sample acquisition for this project occurred over two field campaigns and included the collection of previously entombed black mosses found along glacier edges and recently glaciated terrain, peat cores from moss peatbanks, and living mosses and lichens for understanding modern processes linking the composition of mosses and water that are relevant to the interpretation of paleorecords (i.e., carbon and oxygen stable isotopes). Collectively, these datasets provided insight into past environmental change on the Antarctic Peninsula and revealed considerable potential for future studies in the region.

Our radiocarbon-dating of black mosses demonstrated three distinct episodes of ice advance in the northern Antarctic Peninsula occurring approximately 1300, 800, and 200 years ago, consistent with other studies and penguin colony abandonment at several sites in the region. Rates of glacier advance at Gamage and Bonaparte Points (southern Anvers Island) were estimated at 2.0 and 0.3 meters per year, respectively, during the advance that took place 800 years ago. When our terrestrial evidence for glacier advances is viewed alongside other paleoenvironmental records, it suggests regional synchroneity of glacial dynamics and cryosphere-biosphere connections during rapid climate shifts of the past, and also the high-sensitivity of terrestrial ecosystems to past climate change. Our peat core work demonstrated the potential of paleoenvironmental reconstruction from peatbanks in the region, although our analyses of a 100-cm long core from Litchfield Island revealed that not all proxies observed in other similar systems were well preserved. Analysis of moss tissue waters revealed an evaporative signal relative to precipitation and standing water. Topographic aspect mediates the moss water isotopic fingerprint, which is an important consideration for paleoclimate interpretations from moss peat cores.

In addition to the intellectual merits of the paleoenvironmental work described above, the project had significant broader impacts including training of a post-doctoral scientist and numerous graduate and undergraduate students at the collaborating institutions. The post-doctoral scientist gained experience in fieldwork, data analysis, laboratory techniques, data interpretation, manuscript preparation, and helped mentor undergraduate and graduate students at both Lehigh University and the University of Hawaii. In addition to training the next generation of STEM researchers, the results of the research have been widely disseminated at conference presentations, invited presentations at universities and other institutions, and in journal publications. The post-doctoral scientist also participated in science communication through media interviews and the program “Letters to a Pre-Scientist” intended for scientists to engage with middle school students as pen pals during each year of the grant.
